ayahs.text: Allah swears by the sky that contains constellations, referring to the celestial bodies and stars that adorn the heavens. This divine oath emphasizes the magnificence and orderliness of Allah's creation in the cosmic realm. The constellations serve as signs and markers in the vast expanse of the universe, demonstrating divine wisdom and power. This oath sets the stage for the serious matters that follow in the surah, underlining the gravity of the message through reference to these majestic celestial phenomena.

Allah swears by the Promised Day, which refers to the Day of Judgment that is certain to come. This day represents the ultimate accountability when all souls will face divine justice for their earthly deeds. The certainty of this promised day serves as both a warning to the wrongdoers and comfort to the believers. It emphasizes that divine justice will ultimately prevail, and no injustice will go unanswered. The oath by this day reinforces the themes of accountability and divine retribution that permeate the surah.

Allah swears by the witness and the witnessed, which has been interpreted in various ways by scholars. One significant interpretation identifies the witness as Friday, which comes to people in every city and settlement, while the witnessed refers to the Day of Arafah (10th of Dhul-Hijjah), when people must physically present themselves in the plains of Arafat during Hajj. This verse highlights the concept of divine witnessing and testimony, emphasizing that Allah observes all human actions. The contrast between what comes to people and what people must approach reflects different aspects of divine mercy and human responsibility.

Allah declares that the People of the Trench were destroyed, referring to those who dug ditches and burned believers alive in them. While it appeared that the believers were the ones who perished, in reality, they achieved martyrdom and eternal reward by surrendering their lives to their Creator. The true destruction and loss belonged to the oppressors who committed these heinous acts against innocent believers. This verse establishes the central theme of the surah: that apparent worldly success of oppressors masks their ultimate spiritual destruction, while the suffering of believers leads to their eternal triumph.

This verse describes the fire with abundant fuel that was used to burn the believers. The oppressors had gathered extensive combustible materials to create a terrifying and intense blaze for their cruel persecution. The detailed description of this fire emphasizes the calculated and systematic nature of the oppression against the believers. However, this same fire becomes a symbol of the punishment that awaits the oppressors in the afterlife, where they will face consequences for their cruelty.

This verse continues the description of the intense fire that the oppressors prepared for burning the believers. The emphasis on the abundance of fuel highlights the premeditated and systematic nature of their persecution. The fire represents not only the physical torment inflicted upon the believers but also symbolizes the spiritual consequences that await those who commit such atrocities. The verse serves as a reminder that while oppressors may seem to have power in this world, they are ultimately preparing their own punishment in the hereafter.

The oppressors not only ordered the burning of believers but also personally witnessed and observed this horrific spectacle. They positioned themselves around the edges of the trenches to watch the heart-wrenching scene they had orchestrated. This verse reveals the depth of their cruelty and callousness - they took pleasure in witnessing the suffering they inflicted. Historical parallels include systematic persecutions like those carried out by Hitler, who also orchestrated elaborate plans for mass killings, establishing gas chambers and developing scientific methods for disposing of human bodies. Such calculated cruelty demonstrates the extreme moral corruption of those who systematically persecute believers.

This verse reiterates that the oppressors were witnesses to their own cruel actions against the believers. They not only commanded the persecution but actively observed the implementation of their evil orders. Their presence as spectators to such horrific acts reveals their complete moral degradation and lack of human compassion. The repetition emphasizes how they made witnessing the suffering of believers into a form of entertainment or satisfaction. This behavior represents the pinnacle of spiritual corruption, where those in positions of power and authority use their influence to systematically destroy innocent people while deriving pleasure from their suffering.

The verse continues to emphasize the role of the oppressors as active witnesses to their persecution of believers. This repetition underscores the systematic and deliberate nature of their cruelty, highlighting that their actions were not impulsive but carefully planned and executed with conscious observation. The fact that they witnessed their own evil deeds makes their guilt more pronounced and their eventual punishment more justified. Their witnessing also serves as evidence against them on the Day of Judgment, when they will be held accountable for every act they committed against innocent believers.

Allah declares that those who persecute believing men and women and then do not repent will face the punishment of Hell and the torment of burning. This verse establishes the divine principle of justice - that persecution of believers will not go unpunished. However, the mention of repentance indicates that even the worst oppressors can find mercy if they genuinely turn to Allah and seek forgiveness. The specific mention of both believing men and women emphasizes that persecution based on faith affects all believers regardless of gender, and divine justice encompasses protection for all. The punishment of Hell fire serves as divine retribution that mirrors the earthly fire they used against believers.

In contrast to the punishment awaiting oppressors, Allah promises that those who believe and do righteous deeds will have Gardens beneath which rivers flow. This verse presents the beautiful contrast between the fate of the persecuted believers and their persecutors. While the oppressors face fire, the believers enjoy eternal paradise with flowing rivers, representing peace, abundance, and spiritual satisfaction. This is described as the great success, emphasizing that true victory lies not in worldly power or temporary dominance, but in earning Allah's pleasure and eternal reward. The believers who suffered persecution thus achieve the ultimate triumph through their faith and patience.

Allah's grip and seizure is indeed severe when He takes hold of individuals or nations for their wrongdoing. This verse serves as a warning about divine retribution that comes to those who transgress Allah's boundaries and oppress His believers. When Allah decides to punish oppressors, His grasp is inescapable and overwhelming. Historical examples demonstrate how mighty empires and powerful rulers have fallen when they crossed the limits set by Allah. The severity of divine seizure should cause reflection among those who commit injustices, reminding them that earthly power is temporary and divine justice is certain.

Allah is the One who creates initially and then recreates or resurrects. This verse emphasizes Allah's power over both the beginning and the end of creation, highlighting His ability to bring life into existence and then restore it after death. The concept of initial creation refers to bringing everything into being from nothingness, while recreation refers to the resurrection on the Day of Judgment when all souls will be brought back to life. This divine attribute provides comfort to believers facing persecution, assuring them that the God who created them has the power to resurrect them and grant them eternal life in paradise.

Allah is described as the Forgiving and Loving, two beautiful attributes that provide hope and comfort to believers. His forgiveness encompasses all sins for those who sincerely repent, no matter how grave their transgressions may have been. His love extends to those who turn to Him with sincere hearts and strive to follow His guidance. These attributes balance the themes of divine justice mentioned earlier in the surah, showing that while Allah punishes oppressors, He is equally ready to forgive and show love to those who seek His mercy. Even former oppressors can find redemption through sincere repentance.

Allah is the Owner of the Throne, the Glorious, emphasizing His supreme sovereignty and majesty over all creation. The Throne represents the pinnacle of divine authority and power, from which Allah governs the entire universe. His glory is absolute and incomparable, transcending all earthly concepts of honor and magnificence. This attribute reminds believers that no matter how powerful oppressors may seem, they are ultimately under the authority of Allah, who sits upon the supreme Throne. The mention of divine glory also comforts persecuted believers by reminding them that they serve the most glorious and powerful Lord.

Allah is the One who accomplishes whatever He wills, and nothing can obstruct His intentions or prevent Him from executing His plans. This verse emphasizes divine omnipotence and the certainty of Allah's will being fulfilled. No earthly power, regardless of how mighty it may appear, can stand in the way of what Allah has decreed. This attribute provides ultimate comfort to believers facing persecution, assuring them that Allah's justice will prevail and His promises will be fulfilled. It also serves as a warning to oppressors that their temporary power cannot prevent divine retribution when Allah decides to act against them.

This verse reiterates that Allah accomplishes whatever He wills without any impediment or obstacle. The repetition emphasizes the absolute nature of divine power and the certainty of divine will being executed. No force in creation can prevent Allah from implementing His decisions or achieving His purposes. This principle applies to both divine mercy for believers and divine punishment for oppressors. The verse reinforces the theme that ultimate authority belongs to Allah alone, and all human power is temporary and subject to His supreme will.

This verse continues to emphasize Allah's attribute of accomplishing whatever He wills. The consistent repetition throughout these verses underscores the fundamental principle that divine will is supreme and unobstructable. This truth provides the foundation for all the promises and warnings mentioned in the surah - the punishment of oppressors and reward of believers are both certain because Allah has the absolute power to fulfill His word. The emphasis on divine will also reminds believers to align their own wills with Allah's guidance and commands.

The verse reaffirms that Allah is the ultimate executor of His will, capable of bringing about whatever He intends without any obstruction. This repetition serves to ingrain this fundamental truth in the hearts and minds of believers, especially those facing persecution and oppression. The certainty of divine will being fulfilled means that justice will ultimately prevail, the righteous will be rewarded, and the oppressors will face consequences for their actions. This principle provides hope to the downtrodden and serves as a warning to those who transgress Allah's boundaries.

This verse continues the emphasis on Allah's absolute power to accomplish His will. The repetitive nature of this message throughout these verses demonstrates its critical importance in the context of persecution and oppression. Believers need constant reassurance that despite apparent worldly injustices, divine justice will ultimately triumph. The unobstructed nature of Allah's will means that His promises to believers and warnings to oppressors will certainly be fulfilled, regardless of how circumstances may appear in the temporary context of worldly life.

The verse reiterates Allah's capacity to execute whatever He wills without hindrance. This continued emphasis serves to strengthen the faith of believers and remind them that their Lord's power is absolute and His justice is certain. For those facing persecution, this assurance provides spiritual strength and patience, knowing that their suffering is temporary while Allah's justice is eternal. The repetition also serves as a stern warning to oppressors that they cannot escape divine accountability through their earthly power or influence.

The Quran is preserved in the Preserved Tablet (Lawh Mahfuz), which is with Allah. This verse emphasizes the divine origin and protection of the Quran, assuring believers that Allah's word is eternally preserved and cannot be corrupted or destroyed by human efforts. The Preserved Tablet is also referred to in other parts of the Quran as Umm al-Kitab (Mother of the Book), Kitab Maknun (Hidden Book), and Suhuf Mukarramah Marfu'ah Mutahharah (Honored Pages, Exalted and Purified). This preservation ensures that divine guidance remains accessible to humanity throughout time, providing comfort to believers that they have access to authentic divine revelation despite the efforts of oppressors to suppress the truth.
